TornadoAggregate: Accurate and Scalable Federated Learning
via the Ring-Based Architecture

Jin-woo Lee,1 Jaehoon Oh, 1 Sungsu Lim, 2 Se-Young Yun, 1 Jae-Gil Lee, 1
Abstract

Federated learning has emerged as a new paradigm of collaborative machine learning; however, many prior studies have used global aggregation along a star topology without much consideration of the communication scalability or the diurnal property relied on clients’ local time variety. In contrast, ring architecture can resolve the scalability issue and even satisfy the diurnal property by iterating nodes without an aggregation. Nevertheless, such ring-based algorithms can inherently suffer from the high-variance problem. To this end, we propose a novel algorithm called TornadoAggregate that improves both accuracy and scalability by facilitating the ring architecture. In particular, to improve the accuracy, we reformulate the loss minimization into a variance reduction problem and establish three principles to reduce variance: Ring-Aware Grouping, Small Ring, and Ring Chaining. Experimental results show that TornadoAggregate improved the test accuracy by up to 26.7%percent26.726.7\% and achieved near-linear scalability.

1 Introduction

Federated learning (Konecˇˇc\check{\text{c}}nỳ et al. 2016a; McMahan et al. 2017b) enables mobile devices to collaboratively learn a shared model while keeping all training data on the devices, thus avoiding data transfer to the cloud or central server. One of the main reasons for this recent boom in federated learning is that it does not compromise user privacy. In this framework, star architecture (Figure 1(a)), which involves a central parameter server aggregating and broadcasting locally learned models, has been most widely adopted in favor of its simple distributed parallelism. However, the star architecture can easily become a communication bottleneck and cannot take into account the diurnal property of federated learning (McMahan et al. 2017a; Eichner et al. 2019), in which the global data distribution of clients significantly varies due to the difference in the clients’ local time.

Ring architecture (Figure 1(b)), in contrast, can resolve the scalability issue and even satisfy the diurnal property by iterating nodes without a central coordinator. In addition, it has the potential to improve accuracy through an unbiased estimation of conventional centralized learning at the expense of communication cost. Notably, Duan et al. (2020) proposed a star architecture with ring-based groups, while Ding et al. (2020) proposed a ring architecture with stars-based groups. Ghosh et al. (2020) and Eichner et al. (2019) proposed star-based and ring-based groups, respectively, without global communication. Other than the importance of addressing the problem, less has been addressed how a ring-based architecture should be developed from the perspective of both accuracy and scalability.

In this paper, we propose a novel TornadoAggregate algorithm that improves both accuracy and scalability by facilitating the ring architecture. To improve accuracy, in particular, TornadoAggregate aims at reducing the variance inherent in a ring iteration by considering three principles: ring-aware grouping, small ring, and ring chaining. Based on the ring-aware grouping principle, for the TornadoAggregate with a global ring (Figure 1(c)) and group rings (Figure 1(d)), nodes are grouped such that it reduces the inter-group variance in the global ring and inter-node variance in each group ring, respectively; the number of groups is adjusted to satisfy the small ring principle, thus achieving the small variance; we introduce ring chaining technique to increase the batch size with high node utilization in a ring, leading to the reduced variance.

We confirmed that TornadoAggregate achieved a higher accuracy by up to 26.7%percent26.726.7\% and near-linear scalability.

2 Architectures of Federated Learning

We first briefly describe federated learning and then survey relevant architectures in terms of accuracy and scalability.

Basics of Federated Learning

Flat Architecture

Flat represents an architecture without hierarchical composition that, in turn, includes STAR and RING architecture. STAR is the same as the canonical FedAvg (McMahan et al. 2017b) without node sampling, as defined by Definition 1.

Definition 1.

STAR involves local update, which learns each local model wisuperscriptwi{\textbf{w}}^{i} with learning rate η𝜂\eta by performing gradient descent steps, and global aggregation, which learns the global model w by aggregating all wisuperscriptwi{\textbf{w}}^{i} along a star topology and synchronizes wisuperscriptwi{\textbf{w}}^{i} with w every ττ\uptau epochs, as in Eq. (2).

STAR exhibits the most simple distributed parallelism that, at the same time, leads to low scalability of O(|𝒩|𝒩\lvert\mathcal{N}\rvert) due to the communication bottleneck in global aggregation.

In contrast, RING (Li et al. 2018; Eichner et al. 2019) resolves the aforementioned scalability issue by removing the global aggregation, as defined by Definition 2.

RING exhibits low convergence bound, attributed to Theorem 1, and benefits from high scalability of O(111). However, it is considered impractical in federated learning, where a large |𝒩|𝒩\lvert\mathcal{N}\rvert is assumed, because it takes |𝒩|𝒩\lvert\mathcal{N}\rvert times as much communication rounds to iterate a global epoch as STAR.

Theorem 1.

RING is an unbiased estimator of the centralized learning that learns a centralized model by assuming the federated datasets to be located at centralized storage.

Owing to lack of space, we defer all proofs to Appendix C.

Consensus Group Architecture

Consensus group represents an architecture with group hierarchy and global communication to reach a global consensus among groups, which, in turn, includes four architectural combinations: STAR-stars, STAR-rings, RING-stars, and RING-rings. First, STAR-stars (Lin et al. 2018; Bonawitz et al. 2019; Liu et al. 2020; Luo et al. 2020; Abad et al. 2020) mitigates the non-IID issue via group-based learning (Zhao et al. 2018), which leads to improved accuracy, as defined by Definition 3.

Definition 3.

STAR-stars extends STAR by additionally allowing multiple intermediate group star aggregations, thus postfixed by stars. In particular, the set of all node indices 𝒩𝒩\mathcal{N} is partitioned into sets of node indices for |𝒢|𝒢\lvert\mathcal{G}\rvert node groups {𝒩k}k=1​…​|𝒢|subscriptsuperscript𝒩𝑘𝑘1…𝒢\{\mathcal{N}^{k}\}_{k=1\ldots\lvert\mathcal{G}\rvert}, where ∪k∈𝒢𝒩k=𝒩subscript𝑘𝒢superscript𝒩𝑘𝒩\cup_{k\in\mathcal{G}}{\mathcal{N}^{k}}=\mathcal{N} and ∀k≠lfor-all𝑘𝑙\forall k\neq l, 𝒩k∩𝒩l=∅superscript𝒩𝑘superscript𝒩𝑙\mathcal{N}^{k}\cap\mathcal{N}^{l}=\emptyset, and 𝒟k≜∪i∈𝒩k𝒟k,i≜superscript𝒟𝑘subscript𝑖superscript𝒩𝑘superscript𝒟𝑘𝑖\mathcal{D}^{k}\triangleq\cup_{i\in\mathcal{N}^{k}}{\mathcal{D}^{k,i}}. Then, for each group, it learns the group model wksuperscriptwk{\textbf{w}}^{k} by aggregating all local models wk,isuperscriptwki{\textbf{w}}^{k,i} along a group star topology and synchronizes wk,isuperscriptwki{\textbf{w}}^{k,i} with wksuperscriptwk{\textbf{w}}^{k} every τ1subscriptτ1\uptau_{1} epochs, as shown by Eq. (4). Similar to Eq. (2), a global aggregation is performed every τ1​τ2subscriptτ1subscriptτ2\uptau_{1}\uptau_{2} steps.

STAR-stars is known to improve STAR under certain parameter settings in favor of the non-IID mitigation (Liu et al. 2020), but it exhibits the low scalability of O(|𝒩|𝒩\lvert\mathcal{N}\rvert).

Next, analogous to the development of RING, STAR-rings (Duan et al. 2020), RING-stars (So, Guler, and Avestimehr 2020; Ding et al. 2020), and RING-rings (Eichner et al. 2019) also aim at improving both convergence bound and scalability while sacrificing communication cost, which are summarized in Table 1. Formal definitions are as follows.

Definition 4.

Similar to Definition 2, STAR-rings extends STAR-stars by replacing the group aggregation with group inter-node transfer that, for each group k∈𝒢𝑘𝒢k\in\mathcal{G}, synchronizes a new model wk,ijsuperscriptwksubscriptij{\textbf{w}}^{k,i_{j}} on node ij∈𝒩ksubscript𝑖𝑗superscript𝒩𝑘i_{j}\in\mathcal{N}^{k} with the previously learned model wk,ij−1superscriptwksubscriptij1{\textbf{w}}^{k,i_{j-1}} on node ij−1subscript𝑖𝑗1i_{j-1} every τ1subscriptτ1\uptau_{1} epochs along a certain ring topology [ij∈𝒩k|j=⌊t/τ1⌋,ij+|𝒩k|=ij]delimited-[]formulae-sequencesubscript𝑖𝑗conditionalsuperscript𝒩𝑘𝑗𝑡subscriptτ1subscript𝑖𝑗superscript𝒩𝑘subscript𝑖𝑗[i_{j}\in\mathcal{N}^{k}|j=\lfloor t/\uptau_{1}\rfloor,i_{j+\lvert\mathcal{N}^{k}\rvert}=i_{j}] with a period |𝒩k|superscript𝒩𝑘\lvert\mathcal{N}^{k}\rvert to satisfy the diurnal property within each group. In short, wtk,i≜wtk≜subscriptsuperscriptwkitsubscriptsuperscriptwkt{\textbf{w}}^{k,i}_{t}\triangleq{\textbf{w}}^{k}_{t} (group aggregation) of Eq. (4) is replaced with wtk,ij≜wtk,ij−1≜subscriptsuperscriptwksubscriptijtsubscriptsuperscriptwksubscriptij1t{\textbf{w}}^{k,i_{j}}_{t}\triangleq{\textbf{w}}^{k,i_{j-1}}_{t} (group inter-node transfer).

Definition 5.

Similar to Definition 4, RING-stars extends STAR-stars by replacing the global aggregation with global inter-group transfer that synchronizes a new local model wkl,isuperscriptwsubscriptkli{\textbf{w}}^{k_{l},i} on node i∈𝒩kl𝑖superscript𝒩subscript𝑘𝑙i\in\mathcal{N}^{k_{l}} with the previously learned group model wkl−1superscriptwsubscriptkl1{\textbf{w}}^{k_{l-1}} in group kl−1subscript𝑘𝑙1k_{l-1} every τ1​τ2subscriptτ1subscriptτ2\uptau_{1}\uptau_{2} steps along a certain ring topology [kl∈𝒢|l=⌊t/(τ1​τ2)⌋,kl+|𝒢|=kl]delimited-[]formulae-sequencesubscript𝑘𝑙conditional𝒢𝑙𝑡subscriptτ1subscriptτ2subscript𝑘𝑙𝒢subscript𝑘𝑙[k_{l}\in\mathcal{G}|l=\lfloor t/\lparen\uptau_{1}\uptau_{2}\rparen\rfloor,k_{l+\lvert\mathcal{G}\rvert}=k_{l}] with a period |𝒢|𝒢\lvert\mathcal{G}\rvert to satisfy the diurnal property across all groups. In short, wtk,i≜wt≜subscriptsuperscriptwkitsubscriptwt{\textbf{w}}^{k,i}_{t}\triangleq{\textbf{w}}_{t} (global aggregation) of Eq. (4) is replaced with wtkl,i≜wtkl−1≜subscriptsuperscriptwsubscriptklitsubscriptsuperscriptwsubscriptkl1t{\textbf{w}}^{k_{l},i}_{t}\triangleq{\textbf{w}}^{k_{l-1}}_{t} (global inter-group transfer).

Definition 6.

RING-rings extends STAR-stars by replacing the group and global aggregation with the group inter-node and global inter-group transfer, respectively.

Similar to RING, RING-rings is considered impractical in federated learning due to large number of nodes.

Pluralistic Group Architecture

Pluralistic group represents an architecture with group hierarchy and without global communication to develop more independent and specialized group models than the aforementioned consensus model, which leads to decreased non-IIDness, and consequently, improved accuracy. Representative pluralistic group includes stars and rings. Recently, stars (Ghosh et al. 2019, 2020; Xie et al. 2020; Briggs et al. 2020; Sattler, Müller, and Samek 2020) has received great attention, which is defined by Definition 7.

Definition 7.

stars is defined as STAR-stars without global aggregation. Unlike Eq. (4), wtk,isubscriptsuperscriptwkit{\textbf{w}}^{k,i}_{t} is not synchronized with wtsubscriptwt{\textbf{w}}_{t} and thus group communication rounds τ2subscriptτ2\uptau_{2} is not defined.

Definition 8.

Similar to Definition 7, rings is defined as STAR-rings without global aggregation.

It is important to note that the growing popularity of pluralistic group architectures may be hype. According to Theorem 2, stars may achieve lower accuracy than STAR.

Theorem 2.

The convergence bound O(δ​h​(τ)𝛿ℎτ\delta h(\uptau)) of stars doesn’t necessarily be better than O(D​h​(τ)𝐷ℎτDh(\uptau)) of STAR.

Lastly, as shown in Table 1, rings can benefit from the low convergence bound as well as high scalability of O(|𝒢|𝒢\lvert\mathcal{G}\rvert).

3 Reformulation: Variance Reduction

As previously noted, ring-based architectures such as RING, STAR-rings, RING-stars, Ring-rings, and rings have great potential to improve both accuracy and scalability. However, the convergence analysis framework introduced in this study is mostly based on unbiasedness property to easily compare all of the architectures. To better understand architectures from the perspective of accuracy, the variance should also be further considered. To this end, based on Theorem 3, we reformulate the problem of Eq. (1) to the variance reduction of ring-based architectures.

Theorem 3.

RING exhibits higher variance than the centralized learning (unbiased estimator of RING from Theorem 1).

4 Proposed Algorithm: TornadoAggregate

The ring-based federated learning under high variance issue looks similar to the continual learning under catastrophic forgetting (Parisi et al. 2019), but the former additionally involves partitioned data groups as well as data iteration along a ring. Considering the differences, we establish three principles to reduce variance.

  • •

    Principle 1 (Ring-Aware Grouping): For architectures with group rings, nodes should be clustered so that inter-node variance becomes low within a group. On the other hand, for architectures with a global ring, nodes should be IID grouped so that inter-group variance becomes low.

  • •

    Principle 2 (Small Ring): It is straightforward that, the smaller a ring, the lower its iteration variance.

  • •

    Principle 3 (Ring Chaining): A ring can have multiple iteration chains (Ding et al. 2020), each of which iterates the same ring at a different starting node and thus learns an unbiased model different from each other. Multiple chains can reduce learning variance, which is attributed to the reduced variance from increased batch size.

Based on the abovementioned principles, we propose a novel ring-based algorithm called TornadoAggregate and derive two heuristics according to the architecture type. We refer to TornadoAggregate with RING-stars and STAR-rings as Tornado and Tornadoes, respectively. In particular, for the ring-aware grouping principle, Tornado and Tornadoes require nodes to be IID grouped and clustered, respectively; for the small ring principle, Tornado and Tornadoes require a small and large number of groups, respectively; for the ring chaining principle, both require a large number of chains.

As shown in Algorithm 1, Tornado takes the node set 𝒩𝒩\mathcal{N} and the number of groups |𝒢|𝒢\lvert\mathcal{G}\rvert, chains C𝐶C, epochs τ1subscriptτ1\uptau_{1}, and communication rounds τ2subscriptτ2\uptau_{2} as input and returns the final model wTsubscriptwT{\textbf{w}}_{T} as output. It begins by initializing all local models w0k,isubscriptsuperscriptwki0{\textbf{w}}^{k,i}_{0}, a randomly permuted inter-group ring [kl]delimited-[]subscript𝑘𝑙[k_{l}], and group indices {𝒩k}superscript𝒩𝑘\{\mathcal{N}^{k}\} via the IID node grouping (Lines 1–3). Then, for each chain and each node, the local updates are performed (Lines 5–8); each group model is learned by aggregating all local models every τ1subscriptτ1\uptau_{1} epochs (Lines 9–10) and is transferred to all nodes in the next group kn​e​x​tsubscript𝑘𝑛𝑒𝑥𝑡k_{next} every τ1​τ2subscriptτ1subscriptτ2\uptau_{1}\uptau_{2} steps (Lines 11–13). Overall, Lines 4–13 repeat for T𝑇T steps.

Because Tornado and Tornadoes are inherently correlated, we defer the description of Tornadoes to Appendix D.

5 Evaluation

Experimental Setting

Benchmark Datasets and Models

We used two official benchmark datasets and models provided by FedML.

  • •

    FedShakespeare on RNN consists of 715 nodes with 16068 train and 2356 test examples. RNN is the same as the one proposed by McMahan et al. (2017b).

  • •

    MNIST on logistic regression consists of 1000 nodes with 10 classes of 61664 train and 7371 test examples.

Algorithms

In Table 2, the proposed Tornado and Tornadoes are compared with five state-of-the-art algorithms in terms of group type and number of chains.

Results

Figure 2 shows the test accuracy for FedShakespeare dataset. Tornadoes outperformed the state-of-the-art algorithms by up to 26.7%percent26.726.7\% and the next best group (Tornado, FedAvg, and HierFAVG) by 4.4%percent4.44.4\% on average. The low performance of Tornado relative to Tornadoes is attributed to the communication interval; Tornado(RING-stars) takes τ1​τ2subscriptτ1subscriptτ2\uptau_{1}\uptau_{2} steps for a global inter-group transfer in the RING, which is larger than τ1subscriptτ1\uptau_{1} steps of Tornadoes (STAR-rings) for a group inter-node transfer in each ring, thus causing higher divergence. The poor performances of Astraea and MM-PSGD come from the high variance caused by the inappropriate node grouping and low chain utilization. Lastly, IFCA achieved the worst accuracy due to the difficulty of clustering FedShakespeare dataset, as explained by the small clustering cost reduction of only 4.3%percent4.34.3\%, in which case the relationship between FedAvg and IFCA is consistent with Theorem 2.

Figure 3 shows the communication scalability to the number of nodes ranging from 505050 to 500500500 for MNIST dataset. For each case, we measured the communication data size in bytes to reach the converged train accuracy of the case with 505050 nodes (73%percent7373\% for FedAvg and 79%percent7979\% for Tornadoes) and showed the improvement relative to that case. Tornadoes achieved near-linear scalability, which is attributed to the superior communication scalability cost of STAR-rings.

7 Conclusion

In this paper, we provided a comprehensive survey of learning architectures in terms of accuracy and scalability. Our formal analysis led to the necessity of ring-based architecture and its inherent variance reduction problem. To this end, we proposed a novel ring-based algorithm TornadoAggregate that improves both scalability and accuracy by reducing variance in a ring iteration. Experimental results show that, compared with the state-of-the-art algorithms, TornadoAggregate improved the test accuracy by up to 26.7%percent26.726.7\% and achieved near-linear scalability. Overall, we believe that our novel ring-based algorithm has made important steps towards accurate and scalable federated learning.

Appendix A Convergence Analysis

In this section, we analyze convergence for STAR-stars and then extend it to the rest of architectures.

Convergence Analysis for STAR-stars

First of all, we make the following assumption for the loss function Fk,isuperscript𝐹𝑘𝑖F^{k,i}, as in many other relevant studies (Liu et al. 2020; Wang et al. 2019b).

Assumption 1.

For every i𝑖i and k𝑘k, (1) Fk,isuperscript𝐹𝑘𝑖F^{k,i} is convex; (2) Fk,isuperscript𝐹𝑘𝑖F^{k,i} is ρ𝜌\rho-Lipschitz, i.e., ∥Fk,i​(w)−Fk,i​(w′)∥≤ρ​∥w−w′∥delimited-∥∥superscript𝐹𝑘𝑖wsuperscriptFkisuperscriptw′𝜌delimited-∥∥wsuperscriptw′\lVert F^{k,i}({\textbf{w}})-F^{k,i}({\textbf{w}}^{\prime})\rVert\leq\rho\lVert{\textbf{w}}-{\textbf{w}}^{\prime}\rVert for any w and w′superscriptw′{\textbf{w}}^{\prime}; and (3) Fk,isuperscript𝐹𝑘𝑖F^{k,i} is β𝛽\beta-smooth, i.e., ∥∇Fk,i​(w)−∇Fk,i​(w′)∥≤β​∥w−w′∥delimited-∥∥∇superscript𝐹𝑘𝑖w∇superscriptFkisuperscriptw′𝛽delimited-∥∥wsuperscriptw′\lVert\nabla F^{k,i}({\textbf{w}})-\nabla F^{k,i}({\textbf{w}}^{\prime})\rVert\leq\beta\lVert{\textbf{w}}-{\textbf{w}}^{\prime}\rVert for any w and w′superscriptw′{\textbf{w}}^{\prime}.

Under this assumption, Lemma 1 holds for the group and global loss functions. Fksubscript𝐹𝑘F_{k}, which is the loss function for a node group, is additionally considered here unlike Wang et al. (2019b).

Lemma 1.

F𝐹F and Fksuperscript𝐹𝑘F^{k} are convex, ρ𝜌\rho-Lipschitz, and β𝛽\beta-smooth.

Proof.

It is straightforward from Assumption 1 and the definitions of F𝐹F and Fksuperscript𝐹𝑘F^{k} in Definition 3. ∎

We introduce two types of intervals depending on the learning level: a group interval, [r]≜[(r−1)​τ1,r​τ1]≜delimited-[]𝑟𝑟1subscriptτ1𝑟subscriptτ1[r]\triangleq[\lparen r-1\rparen\uptau_{1},r\uptau_{1}], indicates an interval between two successive group aggregations, and a global interval, [l]≜[(l−1)​τ1​τ2,l​τ1​τ2]≜delimited-[]𝑙𝑙1subscriptτ1subscriptτ2𝑙subscriptτ1subscriptτ2[l]\triangleq[\lparen l-1\rparen\uptau_{1}\uptau_{2},l\uptau_{1}\uptau_{2}], indicates an interval between two successive global aggregations.

Next, we introduce the notion of group-based virtual learning in Definition 9, where training data is assumed to exist on a virtual central repository for each model. This notion is used to bridge the local-to-group divergence (i.e., the divergence between a local model and a group model) in a group interval and the group-to-global divergence (i.e., the divergence between a group model and a global model) in a global interval.

Definition 9 (Group-Based Virtual Learning).

Given a certain group membership z, for any k𝑘k, [r]delimited-[]𝑟[r], and [l]delimited-[]𝑙[l], the virtual group model v[r]ksubscriptsuperscriptvkdelimited-[]r{\textbf{v}}^{k}_{[r]} and virtual global model v[l]subscriptvdelimited-[]l{\textbf{v}}_{[l]} are updated by performing gradient descent steps on the centralized data examples for 𝒩ksuperscript𝒩𝑘\mathcal{N}^{k} and 𝒩𝒩\mathcal{N}, respectively, and synchronized with the federated group model wksuperscriptwk{\textbf{w}}^{k} and the global model w at the beginning of each interval, as in Eq. (5).

v[r],tk≜{wtkif​t=(r−1)​τ1,v[r],t−1k−η​∇Fk​(v[r],t−1k)otherwise≜subscriptsuperscriptvkdelimited-[]rtcasessubscriptsuperscriptwktiftr1subscriptτ1subscriptsuperscriptvkdelimited-[]rt1𝜂∇superscriptFksubscriptsuperscriptvkdelimited-[]rt1otherwise\displaystyle{\textbf{v}}^{k}_{[r],t}\triangleq\begin{dcases}{\textbf{w}}^{k}_{t}&{\text{if}}~{}t=\lparen r-1\rparen\uptau_{1},\\ {\textbf{v}}^{k}_{[r],t-1}-\eta\nabla F^{k}\lparen{\textbf{v}}^{k}_{[r],t-1}\rparen&{\text{otherwise}}\end{dcases} (5)
v[l],t≜{wtif​t=(l−1)​τ1​τ2,v[l],t−1−η​∇F​(v[l],t−1)otherwise≜subscriptvdelimited-[]ltcasessubscriptwtiftl1subscriptτ1subscriptτ2subscriptvdelimited-[]lt1𝜂∇Fsubscriptvdelimited-[]lt1otherwise\displaystyle{\textbf{v}}_{[l],t}\triangleq\begin{dcases}{\textbf{w}}_{t}&{\text{if}}~{}t=\lparen l-1\rparen\uptau_{1}\uptau_{2},\\ {\textbf{v}}_{[l],t-1}-\eta\nabla F\lparen{\textbf{v}}_{[l],t-1}\rparen&{\text{otherwise}}\end{dcases}

To facilitate the interpretation, Figure 4 shows how a virtual model v is updated, following Definition 9. For example, v[l]subscriptvdelimited-[]l{\textbf{v}}_{\left[l\right]} starts diverging from w after (l−1)​τ1​τ2𝑙1subscriptτ1subscriptτ2(l-1)\uptau_{1}\uptau_{2} and becomes synchronized with w at l​τ1​τ2𝑙subscriptτ1subscriptτ2l\uptau_{1}\uptau_{2}.

Then, we formalize group-based gradient divergence in Definition 10 that models the impact of the difference in data distributions across nodes on federated learning.

Definition 10 (Group-Based Gradient Divergence).

Given a certain group membership z, for any i𝑖i and k𝑘k, δk,isuperscript𝛿𝑘𝑖\delta^{k,i} is defined as the gradient difference between the i𝑖i-th local loss and the k𝑘k-th group loss; ΔksuperscriptΔ𝑘\Delta^{k} is defined as the gradient difference between the k𝑘k-th group loss and the global loss, which can be expressed as Eq. (6).

δk,i≜maxw⁡∥∇Fk,i​(w)−∇Fk​(w)∥,Δk≜maxw⁡∥∇Fk​(w)−∇F​(w)∥formulae-sequence≜superscript𝛿𝑘𝑖subscriptw∇superscript𝐹𝑘𝑖w∇superscriptFkw≜superscriptΔ𝑘subscriptw∇superscript𝐹𝑘w∇Fw\begin{gathered}\delta^{k,i}\triangleq\max_{{\textbf{w}}}\lVert\nabla F^{k,i}\lparen{\textbf{w}}\rparen-\nabla F^{k}\lparen{\textbf{w}}\rparen\rVert,\\ \Delta^{k}\triangleq\max_{{\textbf{w}}}\lVert\nabla F^{k}\lparen{\textbf{w}}\rparen-\nabla F\lparen{\textbf{w}}\rparen\rVert\end{gathered} (6)

Then, the local-to-group divergence δ𝛿\delta and the group-to-global divergence ΔΔ\Delta are formulated as Eq. (7).

δ≜∑k∈𝒢∑i∈𝒩k|𝒟k,i||𝒟|​δk,i,Δ≜∑k∈𝒢|𝒟k||𝒟|​Δkformulae-sequence≜𝛿subscript𝑘𝒢subscript𝑖superscript𝒩𝑘superscript𝒟𝑘𝑖𝒟superscript𝛿𝑘𝑖≜Δsubscript𝑘𝒢superscript𝒟𝑘𝒟superscriptΔ𝑘\delta\triangleq\sum_{k\in\mathcal{G}}{\sum_{i\in\mathcal{N}^{k}}{\frac{\lvert\mathcal{D}^{k,i}\rvert}{\lvert\mathcal{D}\rvert}\delta^{k,i}}},~{}~{}\Delta\triangleq\sum_{k\in\mathcal{G}}{\frac{\lvert\mathcal{D}^{k}\rvert}{\lvert\mathcal{D}\rvert}\Delta^{k}} (7)

Based on Definition 9 and 10, we introduce an auxiliary lemma (Lemma 2).

Lemma 2.

For any [r]delimited-[]𝑟[r], [l]delimited-[]𝑙[l], and t∈[(r−1)​τ1,r​τ1]⊂[(l−1)​τ1​τ2,l​τ1​τ2]𝑡𝑟1subscriptτ1𝑟subscriptτ1𝑙1subscriptτ1subscriptτ2𝑙subscriptτ1subscriptτ2t\in[\lparen r-1\rparen\uptau_{1},r\uptau_{1}]\subset[\lparen l-1\rparen\uptau_{1}\uptau_{2},l\uptau_{1}\uptau_{2}], an upper bound of the norm of the difference between a local model and the virtual global model can be expressed as Eq. (8).

∥wtk,i−v[l],t∥≤δk,iβ​((η​β+1)t−(r−1)​τ1−1)+Δkβ​((η​β+1)t−(l−1)​τ1​τ2−1)delimited-∥∥subscriptsuperscriptwkitsubscriptvdelimited-[]ltsuperscript𝛿ki𝛽superscript𝜂𝛽1tr1subscriptτ11superscriptΔ𝑘𝛽superscript𝜂𝛽1𝑡𝑙1subscriptτ1subscriptτ21\begin{multlined}\lVert{\textbf{w}}^{k,i}_{t}-{\textbf{v}}_{[l],t}\rVert\leq\frac{\delta^{k,i}}{\beta}\lparen\lparen\eta\beta+1\rparen^{t-\lparen r-1\rparen\uptau_{1}}-1\rparen\\ +\frac{\Delta^{k}}{\beta}\lparen\lparen\eta\beta+1\rparen^{t-\lparen l-1\rparen\uptau_{1}\uptau_{2}}-1\rparen\end{multlined}\lVert{\textbf{w}}^{k,i}_{t}-{\textbf{v}}_{[l],t}\rVert\leq\frac{\delta^{k,i}}{\beta}\lparen\lparen\eta\beta+1\rparen^{t-\lparen r-1\rparen\uptau_{1}}-1\rparen\\ +\frac{\Delta^{k}}{\beta}\lparen\lparen\eta\beta+1\rparen^{t-\lparen l-1\rparen\uptau_{1}\uptau_{2}}-1\rparen (8)
Proof.

From the triangle inequality, one can simply derive Eq. (9).

∥wtk,i−v[l],t∥=∥wtk,i−v[r],tk+v[r],tk−v[l],t∥≤∥wtk,i−v[r],tk∥+∥v[r],tk−v[l],t∥delimited-∥∥subscriptsuperscriptwkitsubscriptvdelimited-[]ltdelimited-∥∥subscriptsuperscriptwkitsubscriptsuperscriptvkdelimited-[]rtsubscriptsuperscriptvkdelimited-[]rtsubscriptvdelimited-[]ltdelimited-∥∥subscriptsuperscriptwkitsubscriptsuperscriptvkdelimited-[]rtdelimited-∥∥subscriptsuperscriptvkdelimited-[]rtsubscriptvdelimited-[]lt\begin{multlined}\lVert{\textbf{w}}^{k,i}_{t}-{\textbf{v}}_{[l],t}\rVert=\lVert{\textbf{w}}^{k,i}_{t}-{\textbf{v}}^{k}_{[r],t}+{\textbf{v}}^{k}_{[r],t}-{\textbf{v}}_{[l],t}\rVert\\ \leq\lVert{\textbf{w}}^{k,i}_{t}-{\textbf{v}}^{k}_{[r],t}\rVert+\lVert{\textbf{v}}^{k}_{[r],t}-{\textbf{v}}_{[l],t}\rVert\end{multlined}\lVert{\textbf{w}}^{k,i}_{t}-{\textbf{v}}_{[l],t}\rVert=\lVert{\textbf{w}}^{k,i}_{t}-{\textbf{v}}^{k}_{[r],t}+{\textbf{v}}^{k}_{[r],t}-{\textbf{v}}_{[l],t}\rVert\\ \leq\lVert{\textbf{w}}^{k,i}_{t}-{\textbf{v}}^{k}_{[r],t}\rVert+\lVert{\textbf{v}}^{k}_{[r],t}-{\textbf{v}}_{[l],t}\rVert (9)

To conclude this proof, it thus suffices to show Eq. (10) and (11).

∥wtk,i−v[r],tk∥≤delimited-∥∥subscriptsuperscriptwkitsubscriptsuperscriptvkdelimited-[]rtabsent\displaystyle\lVert{\textbf{w}}^{k,i}_{t}-{\textbf{v}}^{k}_{[r],t}\rVert\leq δk,iβ​((η​β+1)t−(r−1)​τ1−1)superscript𝛿𝑘𝑖𝛽superscript𝜂𝛽1𝑡𝑟1subscriptτ11\displaystyle\frac{\delta^{k,i}}{\beta}\lparen\lparen\eta\beta+1\rparen^{t-\lparen r-1\rparen\uptau_{1}}-1\rparen\quad (10)
∥v[r],tk−v[l],t∥≤delimited-∥∥subscriptsuperscriptvkdelimited-[]rtsubscriptvdelimited-[]ltabsent\displaystyle\lVert{\textbf{v}}^{k}_{[r],t}-{\textbf{v}}_{[l],t}\rVert\leq Δkβ​((η​β+1)t−(l−1)​τ1​τ2−1)superscriptΔ𝑘𝛽superscript𝜂𝛽1𝑡𝑙1subscriptτ1subscriptτ21\displaystyle\frac{\Delta^{k}}{\beta}\lparen\lparen\eta\beta+1\rparen^{t-\lparen l-1\rparen\uptau_{1}\uptau_{2}}-1\rparen (11)

Then, by putting Eq. (10) and (11) into Eq. (9), we can confirm Lemma 2.

Both Eq. (10) and (11) can be easily drawn from the β𝛽\beta-smooth property of Fk,isuperscript𝐹𝑘𝑖F^{k,i} and Fksuperscript𝐹𝑘F^{k}. From Eq. (4) and (6), we can derive Eq. (12).

The last inequality stems from the β𝛽\beta-smoothness of Fk,isuperscript𝐹𝑘𝑖F^{k,i} and Definition 10.

Then, since wtk,i=wtk=v[r],tksubscriptsuperscriptwkitsubscriptsuperscriptwktsubscriptsuperscriptvkdelimited-[]rt{\textbf{w}}^{k,i}_{t}={\textbf{w}}^{k}_{t}={\textbf{v}}^{k}_{[r],t} at every group aggregation from Eq. (4) and (6), Eq. (12) can be rewritten as Eq. (13).

∥wtk,i−v[r],tk∥≤delimited-∥∥subscriptsuperscriptwkitsubscriptsuperscriptvkdelimited-[]rtabsent\displaystyle\lVert{\textbf{w}}^{k,i}_{t}-{\textbf{v}}^{k}_{[r],t}\rVert\leq η​δk,i​∑y=1t−(r−1)​τ1(η​β+1)y−1𝜂superscript𝛿𝑘𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑡𝑟1subscriptτ1𝑦1superscript𝜂𝛽1𝑦1\displaystyle\eta\delta^{k,i}\sum^{t-\lparen r-1\rparen\uptau_{1}}_{y=1}{\lparen\eta\beta+1\rparen^{y-1}}
=\displaystyle= δk,iβ​((η​β+1)t−(r−1)​τ1−1)superscript𝛿𝑘𝑖𝛽superscript𝜂𝛽1𝑡𝑟1subscriptτ11\displaystyle\frac{\delta^{k,i}}{\beta}\lparen\lparen\eta\beta+1\rparen^{t-\lparen r-1\rparen\uptau_{1}}-1\rparen (13)

Analogously, one can derive Eq. (11). This is the end of the proof of Lemma 2. ∎

From Lemma 2 and Jensen’s inequality, for all t𝑡t and q𝑞q, we have Eq. (14).

∥wt−v[l],t∥≤∑k∈𝒢∑i∈𝒩k|𝒟k,i||𝒟|​∥wtk,i−v[l],t∥≤δβ​((η​β+1)τ1−1)+Δβ​((η​β+1)τ1​τ2−1)delimited-∥∥subscriptwtsubscriptvdelimited-[]ltsubscriptk𝒢subscriptisuperscript𝒩ksuperscript𝒟ki𝒟delimited-∥∥subscriptsuperscriptwkitsubscriptvdelimited-[]lt𝛿𝛽superscript𝜂𝛽1subscriptτ11Δ𝛽superscript𝜂𝛽1subscriptτ1subscriptτ21\begin{multlined}\lVert{\textbf{w}}_{t}-{\textbf{v}}_{[l],t}\rVert\leq\sum_{k\in\mathcal{G}}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{N}^{k}}\frac{\lvert\mathcal{D}^{k,i}\rvert}{\lvert\mathcal{D}\rvert}\lVert{\textbf{w}}^{k,i}_{t}-{\textbf{v}}_{[l],t}\rVert\\ \leq\frac{\delta}{\beta}\lparen\lparen\eta\beta+1\rparen^{\uptau_{1}}-1\rparen+\frac{\Delta}{\beta}\lparen\lparen\eta\beta+1\rparen^{\uptau_{1}\uptau_{2}}-1\rparen\end{multlined}\lVert{\textbf{w}}_{t}-{\textbf{v}}_{[l],t}\rVert\leq\sum_{k\in\mathcal{G}}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{N}^{k}}\frac{\lvert\mathcal{D}^{k,i}\rvert}{\lvert\mathcal{D}\rvert}\lVert{\textbf{w}}^{k,i}_{t}-{\textbf{v}}_{[l],t}\rVert\\ \leq\frac{\delta}{\beta}\lparen\lparen\eta\beta+1\rparen^{\uptau_{1}}-1\rparen+\frac{\Delta}{\beta}\lparen\lparen\eta\beta+1\rparen^{\uptau_{1}\uptau_{2}}-1\rparen (14)

Finally, for STAR-stars, we derive the convergence bound between the federated global model and the virtual global model by Theorem 4.

Theorem 4 (Convergence Bound of STAR-stars).

For any global interval [l]delimited-[]𝑙[l] and t∈[l]𝑡delimited-[]𝑙t\in[l], if Fk,isuperscript𝐹𝑘𝑖F^{k,i} is β𝛽\beta-smooth for every i𝑖i and k𝑘k in Eq. (6), then Eq. (15) holds.

F​(wt)−F​(v[l],t)≤ρβ​(δ​h​(τ1)+Δ​h​(τ1​τ2))where​h​(t)≜(η​β+1)t−1𝐹subscriptwtFsubscriptvdelimited-[]lt𝜌𝛽𝛿hsubscriptτ1Δhsubscriptτ1subscriptτ2whereht≜superscript𝜂𝛽1t1\begin{split}F\lparen{\textbf{w}}_{t}\rparen-F\lparen{\textbf{v}}_{[l],t}\rparen\leq\frac{\rho}{\beta}\lparen\delta h\lparen\uptau_{1}\rparen+\Delta h\lparen\uptau_{1}\uptau_{2}\rparen\rparen\\ {\text{where}}~{}h\lparen t\rparen\triangleq\lparen\eta\beta+1\rparen^{t}-1\end{split} (15)

Convergence Analysis for the Other Architectures

In this section we analyze convergence bounds for flat architectures (STAR and RING), consensus group architectures (STAR-rings, RING-stars, and RING-rings, and pluralistic group architectures (stars and rings). First, the convergence bound of STAR is the same as that of STAR-stars with no group |𝒢|=1𝒢1\lvert\mathcal{G}\rvert=1 and no group communication τ2=1subscriptτ21\uptau_{2}=1, as in Eq. (16). By excluding the notion of groups, it also means that the group-to-global divergence ΔΔ\Delta becomes 00 and thus the local-to-group divergence δ𝛿\delta becomes the local-to-global divergence D𝐷D, which is extended from Eq. (6) and (7).

F​(wt)−F​(v[l],t)𝐹subscriptwtFsubscriptvdelimited-[]lt\displaystyle F\lparen{\textbf{w}}_{t}\rparen-F\lparen{\textbf{v}}_{[l],t}\rparen ≤ρβ​D​h​(τ)absent𝜌𝛽𝐷ℎτ\displaystyle\leq\frac{\rho}{\beta}Dh\lparen\uptau\rparen (16)
where D≜∑i∈𝒩|𝒟i||𝒟|​Di≜𝐷subscript𝑖𝒩superscript𝒟𝑖𝒟superscript𝐷𝑖\displaystyle~{}D\triangleq\sum_{i\in\mathcal{N}}{\frac{\lvert\mathcal{D}^{i}\rvert}{\lvert\mathcal{D}\rvert}D^{i}}
and Di≜maxw⁡∥∇Fi​(w)−∇F​(w)∥≜superscript𝐷𝑖subscriptw∇superscript𝐹𝑖w∇Fw\displaystyle~{}D^{i}\triangleq\max_{{\textbf{w}}}\lVert\nabla F^{i}\lparen{\textbf{w}}\rparen-\nabla F\lparen{\textbf{w}}\rparen\rVert

Next, the convergence bound of stars is the same as multiple independent STAR groups, where the total node size of stars is the sum of nodes of each STAR group. Thus, by regarding the local-to-global divergence D𝐷D from Eq. (16) of each STAR group as the local-to-group divergence δksuperscript𝛿𝑘\delta^{k} of each group in stars, we have Eq. (17) for stars.

F​(wt)−F​(v[l],t)≤ρβ​δ​h​(τ)𝐹subscriptwtFsubscriptvdelimited-[]lt𝜌𝛽𝛿hτF\lparen{\textbf{w}}_{t}\rparen-F\lparen{\textbf{v}}_{[l],t}\rparen\leq\frac{\rho}{\beta}\delta h\lparen\uptau\rparen (17)

Next, for STAR-rings, similar to Theorem 1, each ring-based learning in a group is an unbiased estimator of the centralized learning within the group because of Eq. (18).

𝔼​[∇Fk,i​(wt)]=∑i∈𝒩k|𝒟k,i||𝒟k|​∇Fk,i​(wt)=∇Fk​(wt)𝔼delimited-[]∇superscript𝐹𝑘𝑖subscriptwtsubscriptisuperscript𝒩ksuperscript𝒟kisuperscript𝒟k∇superscriptFkisubscriptwt∇superscriptFksubscriptwt\mathbb{E}[\nabla F^{k,i}\lparen{\textbf{w}}_{t}\rparen]=\sum_{i\in\mathcal{N}^{k}}{\frac{\lvert\mathcal{D}^{k,i}\rvert}{\lvert\mathcal{D}^{k}\rvert}\nabla F^{k,i}\lparen{\textbf{w}}_{t}\rparen}=\nabla F^{k}\lparen{\textbf{w}}_{t}\rparen (18)

Then, by approximating ∇Fk,i​(wt)∇superscript𝐹𝑘𝑖subscriptwt\nabla F^{k,i}\lparen{\textbf{w}}_{t}\rparen of Eq. (6) to 𝔼​[∇Fk,i​(wt)]𝔼delimited-[]∇superscript𝐹𝑘𝑖subscriptwt\mathbb{E}[\nabla F^{k,i}\lparen{\textbf{w}}_{t}\rparen] of Eq. (18), the local-to-group divergence δ𝛿\delta becomes 00 and thus the group-to-global divergence ΔΔ\Delta becomes the local-to-global divergence D𝐷D. Thus, Eq. (15) is extended to Eq. (19) for STAR-rings.

F​(wt)−F​(v[l],t)≤ρβ​Dh​(τ1​τ2)𝐹subscriptwtFsubscriptvdelimited-[]lt𝜌𝛽Dhsubscriptτ1subscriptτ2F\lparen{\textbf{w}}_{t}\rparen-F\lparen{\textbf{v}}_{[l],t}\rparen\leq\frac{\rho}{\beta}Dh\lparen\uptau_{1}\uptau_{2}\rparen (19)

Next, for RING-stars, similar to Theorem 1, the global RING-based learning is an unbiased estimator of the globally centralized learning in consideration of each stars-based learning in a group because of Eq. (20).

𝔼​[∇Fk​(wt)]=∑k∈𝒢|𝒟k||𝒟|​∇Fk​(wt)=∇F​(wt)𝔼delimited-[]∇superscript𝐹𝑘subscriptwtsubscriptk𝒢superscript𝒟k𝒟∇superscriptFksubscriptwt∇Fsubscriptwt\mathbb{E}[\nabla F^{k}\lparen{\textbf{w}}_{t}\rparen]=\sum_{k\in\mathcal{G}}{\frac{\lvert\mathcal{D}^{k}\rvert}{\lvert\mathcal{D}\rvert}\nabla F^{k}\lparen{\textbf{w}}_{t}\rparen}=\nabla F\lparen{\textbf{w}}_{t}\rparen (20)

Then, by approximating ∇Fk​(wt)∇superscript𝐹𝑘subscriptwt\nabla F^{k}\lparen{\textbf{w}}_{t}\rparen of Eq. (6) to 𝔼​[∇Fk​(wt)]𝔼delimited-[]∇superscript𝐹𝑘subscriptwt\mathbb{E}[\nabla F^{k}\lparen{\textbf{w}}_{t}\rparen] of Eq. (20), the group-to-global divergence ΔΔ\Delta becomes 00 and thus the local-to-group divergence δ𝛿\delta becomes the local-to-global divergence D𝐷D. Thus, Eq. (15) is extended to Eq. (21) for RING-stars.

F​(wt)−F​(v[l],t)≤ρβ​Dh​(τ1)𝐹subscriptwtFsubscriptvdelimited-[]lt𝜌𝛽Dhsubscriptτ1F\lparen{\textbf{w}}_{t}\rparen-F\lparen{\textbf{v}}_{[l],t}\rparen\leq\frac{\rho}{\beta}Dh\lparen\uptau_{1}\rparen (21)

Analogously, from Theorem 1, RING, Ring-rings, and rings can be easily shown to have the approximate convergence bound of 00.

Appendix B Communication Scalability

In this section, we provide an approach to measure communication scalability. For the analysis, M𝑀M denotes the model size; and given the total learning steps T𝑇T, τf≜T/τ≜subscriptτ𝑓𝑇τ\uptau_{f}\triangleq T/\uptau is defined as the number of global communications for the flat architectures; τc≜T/τ1​τ2≜subscriptτ𝑐𝑇subscriptτ1subscriptτ2\uptau_{c}\triangleq T/\uptau_{1}\uptau_{2} is defined as the number of global communications for the consensus group architectures; τp≜T/τ≜subscriptτ𝑝𝑇τ\uptau_{p}\triangleq T/\uptau is defined as the number of group communications for the pluralistic group architectures.

STAR sends M​|𝒩|​τf𝑀𝒩subscriptτ𝑓M\lvert\mathcal{N}\rvert\uptau_{f} of total global aggregation data; RING sends M​τf𝑀subscriptτ𝑓M\uptau_{f} of total global inter-node transfer because only one node is active for the diurnal property; STAR-stars sends M​|𝒩|​(τ2−1)​τc𝑀𝒩subscriptτ21subscriptτ𝑐M\lvert\mathcal{N}\rvert\lparen\uptau_{2}-1\rparen\uptau_{c} of total group aggregation data and M​|𝒩|​τc𝑀𝒩subscriptτ𝑐M\lvert\mathcal{N}\rvert\uptau_{c} of total global aggregation data, thus M​|𝒩|​τ2​τc𝑀𝒩subscriptτ2subscriptτ𝑐M\lvert\mathcal{N}\rvert\uptau_{2}\uptau_{c} of total communication data, which is the same cost as STAR in case of τf=τ2​τcsubscriptτ𝑓subscriptτ2subscriptτ𝑐\uptau_{f}=\uptau_{2}\uptau_{c} as suggested by Liu et al. (2020); stars sends M​|𝒩|​τp𝑀𝒩subscriptτ𝑝M\lvert\mathcal{N}\rvert\uptau_{p} of total group aggregation data, which is the same cost as STAR because τp=τfsubscriptτ𝑝subscriptτ𝑓\uptau_{p}=\uptau_{f} from the definition; analogously, one can show the total communication data size for the rest of architectures, as summarized in Table 1.

Appendix C Deferred Proofs

Theorem 1.

RING is an unbiased estimator of the centralized learning that learns a centralized model by assuming the federated datasets to be located at a centralized storage.

Proof.

The centralized learning is defined as Eq. (22).

wt=wt−1−η​∇F​(wt−1)subscriptwtsubscriptwt1𝜂∇Fsubscriptwt1{\textbf{w}}_{t}={\textbf{w}}_{t-1}-\eta\nabla F\lparen{\textbf{w}}_{t-1}\rparen (22)

Next, for RING update, we regard the model and data communication relationship as the opposite, that is, instead of RING transferring a local model from one node to another while data stays in place, RING is redefined as switching data from one node to another while the local model stays in a certain node. Thus, at the time t𝑡t of data transfer from node i𝑖i to the certain node, Eq. (3) changes to Eq. (23). Note that the index for the certain node is not denoted because it does not need be distinguished from the others.

wt=wt−1−η​∇Fi​(wt−1)subscriptwtsubscriptwt1𝜂∇superscriptFisubscriptwt1{\textbf{w}}_{t}={\textbf{w}}_{t-1}-\eta\nabla F^{i}\lparen{\textbf{w}}_{t-1}\rparen (23)

Thus, Eq. (23) equals the centralized learning in expectation because of Eq. (24)

𝔼​[∇Fi​(wt−1)]=∑i∈𝒩|𝒟i||𝒟|​∇Fi​(wt−1)=∇F​(wt−1)𝔼delimited-[]∇superscript𝐹𝑖subscriptwt1subscripti𝒩superscript𝒟i𝒟∇superscriptFisubscriptwt1∇Fsubscriptwt1\mathbb{E}[\nabla F^{i}\lparen{\textbf{w}}_{t-1}\rparen]=\sum_{i\in\mathcal{N}}{\frac{\lvert\mathcal{D}^{i}\rvert}{\lvert\mathcal{D}\rvert}\nabla F^{i}\lparen{\textbf{w}}_{t-1}\rparen}=\nabla F\lparen{\textbf{w}}_{t-1}\rparen (24)

∎

Theorem 2.

The convergence bound O(δ​h​(τ)𝛿ℎτ\delta h(\uptau)) of stars doesn’t necessarily be better than O(D​h​(τ)𝐷ℎτDh(\uptau)) of STAR.

Proof.

From Eq. (6) and triangle inequality, we have Eq. (25).

δk,i=maxw⁡∥∇Fk,i​(w)−∇Fk​(w)∥superscript𝛿𝑘𝑖subscriptw∇superscript𝐹𝑘𝑖w∇superscriptFkw\displaystyle\delta^{k,i}=\max_{{\textbf{w}}}\lVert\nabla F^{k,i}\lparen{\textbf{w}}\rparen-\nabla F^{k}\lparen{\textbf{w}}\rparen\rVert (25)
=maxw⁡∥∇Fk,i​(w)−∇F​(w)+∇F​(w)−∇Fk​(w)∥absentsubscriptw∇superscript𝐹𝑘𝑖w∇Fw∇Fw∇superscriptFkw\displaystyle=\max_{{\textbf{w}}}\lVert\nabla F^{k,i}\lparen{\textbf{w}}\rparen-\nabla F\lparen{\textbf{w}}\rparen+\nabla F\lparen{\textbf{w}}\rparen-\nabla F^{k}\lparen{\textbf{w}}\rparen\rVert
≤maxw⁡[∥∇Fk,i​(w)−∇F​(w)∥+∥∇F​(w)−∇Fk​(w)∥]absentsubscriptwdelimited-∥∥∇superscript𝐹𝑘𝑖w∇Fwdelimited-∥∥∇Fw∇superscriptFkw\displaystyle\leq\max_{{\textbf{w}}}[\lVert\nabla F^{k,i}\lparen{\textbf{w}}\rparen-\nabla F\lparen{\textbf{w}}\rparen\rVert+\lVert\nabla F\lparen{\textbf{w}}\rparen-\nabla F^{k}\lparen{\textbf{w}}\rparen\rVert]

By summing Eq. (25) for all i𝑖i and k𝑘k and considering Eq. (7) and (16), we have Eq. (26).

δ≤Δ+D𝛿Δ𝐷\delta\leq\Delta+D (26)

Similarly, from Eq. (16) and triangle inequality, we have Eq. (27).

Di=maxw⁡∥∇Fi​(w)−∇F​(w)∥superscript𝐷𝑖subscriptw∇superscript𝐹𝑖w∇Fw\displaystyle D^{i}=\max_{{\textbf{w}}}\lVert\nabla F^{i}\lparen{\textbf{w}}\rparen-\nabla F\lparen{\textbf{w}}\rparen\rVert (27)
=maxw⁡∥∇Fi​(w)−∇Fk​(w)+∇Fk​(w)−∇F​(w)∥absentsubscriptw∇superscript𝐹𝑖w∇superscriptFkw∇superscriptFkw∇Fw\displaystyle=\max_{{\textbf{w}}}\lVert\nabla F^{i}\lparen{\textbf{w}}\rparen-\nabla F^{k}\lparen{\textbf{w}}\rparen+\nabla F^{k}\lparen{\textbf{w}}\rparen-\nabla F\lparen{\textbf{w}}\rparen\rVert
≤maxw⁡[∥∇Fi​(w)−∇Fk​(w)∥+∥∇Fk​(w)−∇F​(w)∥]absentsubscriptwdelimited-∥∥∇superscript𝐹𝑖w∇superscriptFkwdelimited-∥∥∇superscriptFkw∇Fw\displaystyle\leq\max_{{\textbf{w}}}[\lVert\nabla F^{i}\lparen{\textbf{w}}\rparen-\nabla F^{k}\lparen{\textbf{w}}\rparen\rVert+\lVert\nabla F^{k}\lparen{\textbf{w}}\rparen-\nabla F\lparen{\textbf{w}}\rparen\rVert]

By summing Eq. (27) for all i𝑖i and considering Eq. (7), we have Eq. (28).

D≤δ+Δ𝐷𝛿ΔD\leq\delta+\Delta (28)

Lastly, based on Eq. (26) and (28), we can infer that the worst case of δ𝛿\delta equals Δ+DΔ𝐷\Delta+D that is larger than D𝐷D, in which STAR achieves lower convergence bound than stars. ∎

Theorem 3.

RING exhibits higher variance than the centralized learning (unbiased estimator of RING from Theorem 1).

Proof.

First, from the β𝛽\beta-smoothness of F𝐹F and Eq. (22), we have Eq. (29) for centralized learning.

F​(wt)𝐹subscriptwt\displaystyle F\lparen{\textbf{w}}_{t}\rparen =F​(wt−1−η​∇F​(wt−1))absent𝐹subscriptwt1𝜂∇Fsubscriptwt1\displaystyle=F\lparen{\textbf{w}}_{t-1}-\eta\nabla F\lparen{\textbf{w}}_{t-1}\rparen\rparen (29)
≤F​(wt−1)−η​(1−η​β2)​∥∇F​(wt−1)∥2absent𝐹subscriptwt1𝜂1𝜂𝛽2superscriptdelimited-∥∥∇Fsubscriptwt12\displaystyle\leq F\lparen{\textbf{w}}_{t-1}\rparen-\eta\lparen 1-\frac{\eta\beta}{2}\rparen\lVert\nabla F\lparen{\textbf{w}}_{t-1}\rparen\rVert^{2}

Next, from the β𝛽\beta-smoothness of F𝐹F and the definition of RING update in Eq. (23), we have Eq. (30) for RING.

F​(wt)𝐹subscriptwt\displaystyle F\lparen{\textbf{w}}_{t}\rparen =F​(wt−1−η​∇Fi​(wt−1))absent𝐹subscriptwt1𝜂∇superscriptFisubscriptwt1\displaystyle=F\lparen{\textbf{w}}_{t-1}-\eta\nabla F^{i}\lparen{\textbf{w}}_{t-1}\rparen\rparen (30)
≤F​(wt−1)+∇F​(wt−1)​(−η​∇Fi​(wt−1))+η2​β2​∥∇Fi​(wt−1)∥absent𝐹subscriptwt1∇Fsubscriptwt1𝜂∇superscriptFisubscriptwt1superscript𝜂2𝛽2delimited-∥∥∇superscript𝐹𝑖subscriptwt1\displaystyle\begin{multlined}\leq F\lparen{\textbf{w}}_{t-1}\rparen+\nabla F\lparen{\textbf{w}}_{t-1}\rparen\lparen-\eta\nabla F^{i}\lparen{\textbf{w}}_{t-1}\rparen\rparen\\ +\frac{\eta^{2}\beta}{2}\lVert\nabla F^{i}\lparen{\textbf{w}}_{t-1}\rparen\rVert\end{multlined}\leq F\lparen{\textbf{w}}_{t-1}\rparen+\nabla F\lparen{\textbf{w}}_{t-1}\rparen\lparen-\eta\nabla F^{i}\lparen{\textbf{w}}_{t-1}\rparen\rparen\\ +\frac{\eta^{2}\beta}{2}\lVert\nabla F^{i}\lparen{\textbf{w}}_{t-1}\rparen\rVert

In expectation with regard to i𝑖i, we have Eq. (31).

F​(wt)𝐹subscriptwt\displaystyle F\lparen{\textbf{w}}_{t}\rparen ≤F​(wt−1)−η​∥∇F​(wt−1)∥2+η2​β2​𝔼i​∥∇Fi​(wt−1)∥absent𝐹subscriptwt1𝜂superscriptdelimited-∥∥∇Fsubscriptwt12superscript𝜂2𝛽2subscript𝔼𝑖delimited-∥∥∇superscript𝐹𝑖subscriptwt1\displaystyle\begin{multlined}\leq F\lparen{\textbf{w}}_{t-1}\rparen-\eta\lVert\nabla F\lparen{\textbf{w}}_{t-1}\rparen\rVert^{2}\\ +\frac{\eta^{2}\beta}{2}\mathbb{E}_{i}{\lVert\nabla F^{i}\lparen{\textbf{w}}_{t-1}\rparen\rVert}\end{multlined}\leq F\lparen{\textbf{w}}_{t-1}\rparen-\eta\lVert\nabla F\lparen{\textbf{w}}_{t-1}\rparen\rVert^{2}\\ +\frac{\eta^{2}\beta}{2}\mathbb{E}_{i}{\lVert\nabla F^{i}\lparen{\textbf{w}}_{t-1}\rparen\rVert} (31)
≤F​(wt−1)−η​(1−η​β2)​∥∇F​(wt−1)∥2+η2​β2​[𝔼i​∥∇Fi​(wt−1)∥−∥𝔼i​∇Fi​(wt−1)∥2]absent𝐹subscriptwt1𝜂1𝜂𝛽2superscriptdelimited-∥∥∇Fsubscriptwt12superscript𝜂2𝛽2delimited-[]subscript𝔼𝑖delimited-∥∥∇superscript𝐹𝑖subscriptwt1superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝔼i∇superscriptFisubscriptwt12\displaystyle\begin{multlined}\leq F\lparen{\textbf{w}}_{t-1}\rparen-\eta\lparen 1-\frac{\eta\beta}{2}\rparen\lVert\nabla F\lparen{\textbf{w}}_{t-1}\rparen\rVert^{2}\\ +\frac{\eta^{2}\beta}{2}[\mathbb{E}_{i}\lVert\nabla F^{i}\lparen{\textbf{w}}_{t-1}\rparen\rVert-\lVert\mathbb{E}_{i}\nabla F^{i}\lparen{\textbf{w}}_{t-1}\rparen\rVert^{2}]\end{multlined}\leq F\lparen{\textbf{w}}_{t-1}\rparen-\eta\lparen 1-\frac{\eta\beta}{2}\rparen\lVert\nabla F\lparen{\textbf{w}}_{t-1}\rparen\rVert^{2}\\ +\frac{\eta^{2}\beta}{2}[\mathbb{E}_{i}\lVert\nabla F^{i}\lparen{\textbf{w}}_{t-1}\rparen\rVert-\lVert\mathbb{E}_{i}\nabla F^{i}\lparen{\textbf{w}}_{t-1}\rparen\rVert^{2}]

where 𝔼i​∥∇Fi​(wt−1)∥−∥𝔼i​∇Fi​(wt−1)∥2subscript𝔼𝑖delimited-∥∥∇superscript𝐹𝑖subscriptwt1superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝔼i∇superscriptFisubscriptwt12\mathbb{E}_{i}\lVert\nabla F^{i}\lparen{\textbf{w}}_{t-1}\rparen\rVert-\lVert\mathbb{E}_{i}\nabla F^{i}\lparen{\textbf{w}}_{t-1}\rparen\rVert^{2} is the learning variance of RING, which is an added term from Eq. (29).

Analogously, one can show similar variances for STAR-rings, RING-stars, Ring-rings, and rings. ∎

Appendix D TornadoAggregate Details

Algorithm 2 shows the overall procedure of Tornadoes that takes the node set 𝒩𝒩\mathcal{N} and the number of groups |𝒢|𝒢\lvert\mathcal{G}\rvert, chains C𝐶C, epochs τ1subscriptτ1\uptau_{1}, and communication rounds τ2subscriptτ2\uptau_{2} as input and returns the final model wTsubscriptwT{\textbf{w}}_{T} as output. It begins by initializing all local models w0k,isubscriptsuperscriptwki0{\textbf{w}}^{k,i}_{0}, a randomly permuted inter-node ring [ij]delimited-[]subscript𝑖𝑗[i_{j}], and group indices {𝒩k}superscript𝒩𝑘\{\mathcal{N}^{k}\} by clustering nodes (Lines 1–3). Then, for each group and each chain of the group, the local updates are performed at the node i𝑖i (Lines 5–8); every τ1subscriptτ1\uptau_{1} epochs, each local model is transferred to the next node in​e​x​tsubscript𝑖𝑛𝑒𝑥𝑡i_{next} within the same group k𝑘k (Lines 9–11); every τ1​τ2subscriptτ1subscriptτ2\uptau_{1}\uptau_{2} steps, the global model is learned by aggregating all local models and then broadcasts back to all nodes (Lines 12–13). Overall, Lines 4–13 repeat for T𝑇T steps.

We derive another heuristic of TornadoAggregate with rings architecture, called Tornado-rings, which is the same as Tornadoes without the global aggregation to develop a independent and specialized model for each group, i.e., Lines 12–13 of Algorithm 2 are not executed for Tornado-rings. We note that, for the stars and rings, the test performance are measured with the group model of each independent group.

Algorithm 3 shows the two grouping schemes: Group_By_IID and Cluster. Both functions define their own association cost CostAsubscriptCost𝐴\textsc{Cost}_{A} and update cost CostUsubscriptCost𝑈\textsc{Cost}_{U} and, in turn, call Group function with the defined costs. The costs are based on the EMD (earth mover distance) that can approximately model the learning divergences, as proposed by Zhao et al. (2018), which can be expressed as Eq. (32). In Group_By_IID function (Lines 1–4), a group data distribution 𝒟k,isuperscript𝒟𝑘𝑖\mathcal{D}^{k,i} is compared with the global dataset 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} to improve the group-to-global divergence ΔΔ\Delta of Eq. (6), while in Cluster function (Lines 6–9), a local data distribution 𝒟k,isuperscript𝒟𝑘𝑖\mathcal{D}^{k,i} is compared with a group data distribution 𝒟ksuperscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}^{k} to improve the local-to-group divergence δ𝛿\delta of Eq. (6). It should be noted that for the CostUsubscriptCost𝑈\textsc{Cost}_{U} of Group_By_IID function, we had no choice but to use 𝒟k,isuperscript𝒟𝑘𝑖\mathcal{D}^{k,i} instead of 𝒟ksuperscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}^{k} because a cost related to a node should be returned to determine a new medoid node.

EMD​(𝒟1,𝒟2)EMDsubscript𝒟1subscript𝒟2\displaystyle\textsc{EMD}\lparen\mathcal{D}_{1},\mathcal{D}_{2}\rparen (32)
≜∑∀c​l​a​s​s|ℙ​(yj=c​l​a​s​s|j∈𝒟1)−ℙ​(yj=c​l​a​s​s|j∈𝒟2)|≜absentsubscriptfor-all𝑐𝑙𝑎𝑠𝑠ℙsubscript𝑦𝑗conditional𝑐𝑙𝑎𝑠𝑠𝑗subscript𝒟1ℙsubscript𝑦𝑗conditional𝑐𝑙𝑎𝑠𝑠𝑗subscript𝒟2\displaystyle\triangleq\sum_{\forall class}{\lvert\mathbb{P}\lparen y_{j}=class|j\in\mathcal{D}_{1}\rparen-\mathbb{P}\lparen y_{j}=class|j\in\mathcal{D}_{2}\rparen\rvert}

The Group function aims at finding subsets of node indexes for all groups {𝒩k}k=1​…​|𝒢|subscriptsuperscript𝒩𝑘𝑘1…𝒢\{\mathcal{N}^{k}\}_{k=1\ldots\lvert\mathcal{G}\rvert} such that it reduces the defined costs to the extent possible. For this purpose, it begins by selecting random medoid nodes 𝒩msubscript𝒩𝑚\mathcal{N}_{m} of size |𝒢|𝒢\lvert\mathcal{G}\rvert (Line 12). Then, it iteratively updates z by minimizing CostAsubscriptCost𝐴\textsc{Cost}_{A} for all nodes and CostUsubscriptCost𝑈\textsc{Cost}_{U} for all groups until the cost is steady (Lines 14–16).

Appendix E Supplementary Evaluation

Experimental Setting

Configuration

We used FedML (He et al. 2020), one of the most widely used simulation frameworks for federated learning, on PyTorch 1.6.0 to extensively evaluate the performance of various datasets, models, and algorithms.

Parameters

The parameters for both FedShakespeare on RNN and MNIST on logistic regression benchmarks followed those suggested by FedML. The benchmarks used SGD (Stochastic Gradient Descent) optimizer with the learning rate of 0.03. In addition, we randomly sampled 100 nodes for both train and test phase, out of 715 nodes for FedShakespeare and 1000 nodes for MNIST.

Table 4 shows the parameters used for each algorithm. In particular, for the group size, we applied the aforementioned small ring principle to all algorithms such that the group size of an algorithm with IID node grouping, random grouping, and node clustering is set to 2, 5, and 10, respectively, where 10 is considered a reasonably large value for the group size; for the number of chains, we applied the ring chaining principle to the proposed TornadoAggregate heuristics such that the number of chains is set to the number of groups, which is the maximum value by definition; for the communication interval, we firstly determined the product of τ1subscriptτ1\uptau_{1} and τ2subscriptτ2\uptau_{2} of HierFAVG to be equal to ττ\uptau of FedAVG so that HierFAVG can improve accuracy by sacrificing little communication cost, as suggested by Liu et al. (2020), and then we set the same parameters as HierFAVG for the rest of algorithms.

Additional Results

Figure 5 shows the train loss and accuracy of nine algorithms on FedShakespeare dataset. Even though HierFAVG seemingly outrun the others, compared with the test accuracy of HierFAVG in Figure 2, we can infer that it overfit towards the training dataset. Similar to the aforementioned results of IFCA, Tornado-rings performed bad because of the small reduction of clustering cost, defined in Algorithm 3, for FedShakespeare dataset, as shown in Table 3. Low accuracy of SemiCyclic algorithm can be attributed to the low data utilization with low number of active nodes, which is also pointed out by Ding et al. (2020).

Figure 6 shows the train loss and accuracy of all algorithms on MNIST dataset. Interestingly, in contrast to the results for FedShakespeare dataset, Tornado-rings significantly outperformed the others except for closely following IFCA. The reason why the worst performers became the best performers can also be attributed to the large reduction clustering cost, as shown in Table 3. To strike the balance between the two extremes, we leave Tornado-rings as our future work. Aside from Tornado-rings and IFCA, Tornadoes outperformed the others and the rest of algorithms exhibited the similar performance trend to that from FedShakespeare.

Appendix F Future Directions

We consider the following works orthogonal to our work, which can thus be easily extended to by TornadoAggregate.

  • •

    Communication Reduction Techniques: This category includes quantization (Konecˇˇc\check{\text{c}}nỳ et al. 2016a, b), compression (Sattler et al. 2019), or dropout (Caldas et al. 2018).

  • •

    Communication-Aware Learning: This category includes adaptive communication interval (Wang et al. 2019b), communication-constrained learning (Nishio and Yonetani 2019; Yoshida et al. 2019), or multi-objective optimization of learning error and communication (Zhu and Jin 2019).

  • •

    Global-Information Sharing: This category includes sharing a subset of global IID data samples (Zhao et al. 2018; Yoshida et al. 2019), sharing a subset of global data features to scale up the feature-related parameters of a local optimizer (Konecˇˇc\check{\text{c}}nỳ et al. 2016a), or sharing a generative model that can produce an augmented IID dataset (Smith et al. 2017; Jeong et al. 2018).

On the other hand, we aim at improving TornadoAggregate in the following directions.

  • •

    Client Sampling: Client sampling techniques (McMahan et al. 2017b; Sahu et al. 2018; Li et al. 2020) introduce a different variance aspect from those handled in this study.

  • •

    Peer-to-Peer Learning: Other than the star and ring architectures, peer-to-peer (P2P) federated learning (Wang et al. 2019a; Hegedűs, Danner, and Jelasity 2019; Wang et al. 2019a) should also be considered.

  • •

    Transfer Learning: In all synchronizations, model parameters are set to the previously learned model parameters, but we can also consider transferring parameters between different types of models (Jeong et al. 2018; Li and Wang 2019; He, Avestimehr, and Annavaram 2020).

  • •

    Continual Learning: We can extend TornadoAggregate to the novel techniques in the field of continual learning, such as weight decomposition (Yoon et al. 2020) or loss regularization (Shoham et al. 2019).

  • •

    Algorithm Optimization: Other than EMD of Eq. (32), IIDness can also be quantified by loss divergence (Li et al. 2020), gradient divergence (Wang et al. 2019b), or weight divergence (Zhao et al. 2018).
